reviewText: Judge Dawn Hunt, DVD Verdict-- The Midnight RPG is part of the Dungeons & Dragons universe. So why didn't the filmmakers go the extra mile and brand it as such? Did they have so little faith in the public's acceptance of another foray into already tried-and-ultimately-unsuccessful D&D; films?Midnight Chronicles is Christian T. Petersen's baby; he wrote, produced, and directed it. Admittedly, seeing the same person handling all three roles is not necessarily a red flag. Christopher Nolan and Judd Apatow have both made very lucrative careers out of doing exactly that. But that's where the similarities end. For while Nolan has created Inception, The Dark Knight, and The Prestige, and Apatow has offered us The 40-Year-Old Virgin, Knocked Up, and Funny People; there is no way Midnight Chronicles belongs in the same category, no matter whose wacky dream we're exploring or whose baby we're having.The main issue with Midnight Chronicles--it's highly derivative of The Lord of the Rings. There's a dark force we don't see, called Izradur (Sauron). There's a mysterious priest connected to a prophecy, who we don't know whether to trust (Strider/Aragorn). There's a simple farmer who feels too connected to his home and family to be able to leave and fight with the rebels (a combo of Frodo/Sam). The elves fight for the side of hope and the orcs fight for the side of doom, for lack of a better word, just like in Peter Jackson's epic.This movie wanted to be an epic, but with a runtime hovering around 100 minutes it just couldn't. Petersen's cinematic vision was too big for the constraints imposed on it, like people who can't hold a boom mike and editors who didn't pick a better angle.The palette on Midnight Chronicles is completely washed out; intentionally so, but to no benefit I could discern. The white levels were at times completely blown out, making me want to adjust my set. The Dolby 2.0 audio is serviceable, but that's the highest praise I can give it. There are no extras. While that saved me time, there's another version of this DVD out there that at least has some, including the entire RPG the movie is based on. With so little going for it to begin with, why would you take away the extras?-Full review at dvdverdict.com
summary: Any movie during which I can see a boom mike creep into a shot earns my immediate derision
Title: N/A

reviewText: The first sign of cheap in a movie is in the clothing and props (unless it''s a nudist colony documentary). The props (e.g. swords, armor) look like they are made of plastic despite the obvious gray paint. Neither they nor the clothing had a speck of dirt, dust or wear/tear on them. It's as if every person in the village and every person riding horseback on that dirty dusty trail just walked out of KMart. The bad creatures (orcs, I think) wear the same rubber masks that I've seen in past movies and still have that freshly molded look. Same old steer head with horns being paraded about.The second sign of cheap is just a redux of the same old retold movie script of evil forces enslaving mankind with some unknown hero arriving at the last moment to out sword play and magic hand power play the evil Mag.Third sign of cheap is the usual fake Gaelic and late middle ages English dialogue that is getting so old that viewers can recite the lines verbatim after just one word. Gate guard to traveller: "Who goes there?" Traveller: "A servant of the shadow."Fourth sign is the acting which was as real as the props.Fifth sign is a movie that is 95% standing around talking i.e. very very little action. Then the CGI of magic consists of a few moments of swirling light which any kid can create on a laptop with freeware software.

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: The film gives you a quick background to the good vs. evil aspect and thrusts you into a story where it takes you a while to figure out the good guys and bad guys. It copies some of the LOTR aspects in that it includes orcs (bad), elves (good) and humans on both sides. Priests who serve the Shadow are called "legates." With Charles Hubbell playing the lead role of questioning loyalty.There is a prophecy which The Shadow fears where a group of diverse characters lead by one man on a quest will overthrow him and rule Middle Earth er uh.. Baldur's Gate, no wait the world of Aryth. The one legate side kick had a sense of humor and was the only worthwhile character in the group. The dialouge was otherwise dull and dry: "He has help me hide what must remain hidden." Or "In the shadow of the shadow he shall dance with the beast..." There is one scene with side kick and Chuzara where we get to see the microphone overhead. The elves use bows (how did they come up with that?) and speak with bad poetic syntax. We never got to see the "little people."Very little fighting. This appears to be just the first part. A real disappointment of a film. The acting was sad too.No swear words, sex, or nudity.
